choices.text: Isoniazid therapy
Congenital defect in the intestinal and renal transport of neutral amino acids
Carcinoid syndrome
Cystinuria

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with recurrent loose stools, irritability, and memory lapses. On examination, there are bilaterally symmetric, rough, pigmented, scaling lesions on the dorsum of his hands and around his neck in a collar-like distribution. His relatives report personality changes over the last few weeks. Which of the following conditions cannot lead to the clinical syndrome seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, cystinuria does not lead to pellagra, which is being described in the question stem.

  • Niacin refers to nicotinic acid and nicotinamide, both of which are biologically active.
  • Its major role is as the nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes NAD and NADP, which participate in numerous oxidation-reduction reactions, DNA repair, and calcium mobilisation.
  • The body can obtain niacin either directly from food or by converting tryptophan to niacin (≈ 60 mg tryptophan = 1 mg niacin equivalent).
  • Conversion of tryptophan to niacin requires riboflavin, pyridoxine, and iron.
  • Bioavailability: High from animal products (milk, meat, eggs), low from cereals unless enriched with free niacin.
  • Excess niacin (≥ 500 mg/day) may cause flushing, skin irritation, and liver damage.

Pellagra

  • Pellagra arises from the deficiency of niacin or tryptophan.
  • Characterized by the triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, which can progress to death if untreated.
  • The dermatitis is photosensitivity with hyperpigmented, scaling lesions (e.g., Casal's necklace around the neck).
  • Other features include glossitis, vaginitis, esophagitis, abdominal pain, depression, seizures, and psychosis.
  • Pellagra is preventable and treatable with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation (100-200 mg three times daily).

Causes of Pellagra

  1. Dietary deficiency: Seen in populations relying heavily on corn/maize, which is low in bioavailable niacin and tryptophan.
  2. Genetic/metabolic causes:
    • Hartnup disease → defect in intestinal and renal transport of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids → reduced niacin synthesis. (Option B ruled out)
    • Carcinoid syndrome → tryptophan shunted toward serotonin production, reducing its availability for niacin synthesis. (Option C ruled out)
  3. Drug-related: Isoniazid (structural analogue of niacin) can interfere with niacin metabolism and precipitate pellagra. (Option A ruled out)
  4. Micronutrient deficiencies: Lack of riboflavin, vitamin B6, or iron impairs tryptophan-to-niacin conversion.
  5. Alcoholism and malnutrition: Common settings for pellagra in developed regions.

choices.text: Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis
Hydroxylation of proline and leucine residues during collagen synthesis
Cross-linking of collagen fibres due to ATP7A mutation
Cross-linking of collagen fibres due to defective lysyl oxidase

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought with swollen, bleeding gums, irritability, and painful legs. On examination, there are subperiosteal hemorrhages and tenderness of long bones. His diet consists mainly of cow's milk with very little fruit or vegetables. Which of the following enzymatic reactions is primarily impaired in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of scurvy in which hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis is impaired.

  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid and dehydroascorbic acid) is biologically active in humans, primates, guinea pigs, bats, and certain birds, because they lack gulonolactone oxidase needed for endogenous synthesis.
  • Acts as a reducing agent and antioxidant, promoting nonheme iron absorption, collagen formation, catecholamine biosynthesis, carnitine production, and metabolism of peptide hormones.
  • Functions also include roles in DNA/histone demethylation and in mixed-function oxidase enzyme systems.

Enzymatic Roles of Vitamin C

Cofactor for hydroxylases:

  • Proline and lysine hydroxylases → stabilize collagen during its conversion from procollagen. (Option B ruled out)
  • Dopamine β-hydroxylase → converts dopamine to norepinephrine.
  • Peptidylglycine hydroxylase → modifies peptide hormones at their glycine termini.
  • Enzymes for carnitine synthesis (trimethyllysine and γ-butyrobetaine hydroxylases).
  • Required for reducing oxidized iron and copper during enzymatic reactions.

Deficiency - Scurvy

  • Occurs mainly in the poor, elderly, alcoholics with poor diets, and individuals with restricted or unbalanced intake.
  • Symptoms reflect impaired collagen synthesis and catecholamine metabolism.
  • Skin changes, fragile blood vessels, petechiae, perifollicular hemorrhage.
  • Bleeding gums, tooth loss, bone pain or fractures.
  • Fatigue, irritability, psychological changes.
  • Bleeding may extend to joints, peritoneum, pericardium, and adrenal glands.
  • In children: impaired bone growth.
  • Diagnosis: low plasma or leukocyte Vitamin C levels.

Explanation of other options:

Impaired cross-linking of collagen due to ATP7A mutation (Option C): Describes Menke's disease.

Defective cross-linking of collagen due to defective lysyl oxidase (Option D): Consistent with Menke's disease.

choices.text: Alkaline phosphatase
Carbonic anhydrase
Carboxypeptidase A
Pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with chronic diarrhea, poor wound healing, growth retardation, and scaly periorificial dermatitis. His hair is sparse, and he shows delayed puberty. Which of the following enzyme function is least likely to be defective in this boy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is acrodermatitis enteropathica which arises due to zinc deficiency, and among the given options, the enzyme not dependent on zinc is pyruvate dehydrogenase.

  • Zinc is an essential trace element, present in many metalloenzymes and structural proteins.
  • It contributes to the synthesis and stabilization of proteins, DNA, and RNA, and plays a key role in ribosome and membrane structure.
  • Necessary for steroid hormone receptor binding and other transcription factor interactions with DNA.
  • Critical for spermatogenesis, fetal growth, and embryonic development.
  • The human body contains thousands of zinc-containing proteins, including zinc finger transcription factors, which stabilize DNA- and RNA-binding domains.

Enzymes Requiring Zinc

Zinc acts as a cofactor for several enzymes such as:

  • Alkaline phosphatase (Option A ruled out)
  • Carbonic anhydrase (Option B ruled out)
  • Carboxypeptidase A (Option C ruled out)
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Superoxide dismutase (cytosolic form)
  • Phospholipase C, adenosine deaminase, and leucine aminopeptidase

Absorption and Inhibitors

  • Zinc is absorbed in the intestine
  • Absorption is reduced by phytates, fiber, oxalates, iron, and copper, as well as by drugs like penicillamine, sodium valproate, and ethambutol.
  • Bioavailability is higher in animal proteins (meat, shellfish, nuts, legumes) compared to grains and legumes, as phytates in cereals bind zinc and limit absorption.

Zinc Deficiency - Causes

  • Can arise in malabsorption syndromes, chronic illnesses (diabetes, HIV/AIDS, cirrhosis, sickle cell disease, IBD), alcoholism, and with drugs like penicillamine.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica: a rare autosomal recessive condition causing impaired zinc absorption.

Clinical Features of Zinc Deficiency

  • Mild deficiency: growth retardation, impaired taste (hypogeusia), decreased immunity.
  • Severe deficiency: hypogonadism, dwarfism, hypopigmented hair, depression, irritability.
  • Skin and mucosal signs: vesicular and pustular rash around extremities, face, and perineum; scaling and erythema.
  • Other features: alopecia, chronic diarrhea, poor wound healing, muscle wasting, depression, stunted growth, and immune dysfunction.

choices.text: Impaired hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis
Defective antioxidant protection of neuronal membranes and red blood cells against free radical damage
Inability to carry out γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors
Impaired function of thymidylate synthase

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presents with features of fat malabsorption. On examination, he has loss of vibration and position sense, ataxia, and decreased reflexes. He also has mild hemolytic anemia. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely underlying mechanism in this clinical scenario is defective antioxidant protection of neuronal membranes and red blood cells against free radical damage due to vitamin E deficiency.

  • Vitamin E is the collective name for tocopherols and tocotrienols, with α-tocopherol being the most biologically important for humans.
  • It is a lipid-soluble antioxidant that protects cell membranes and plasma lipoproteins from oxidative damage by neutralizing lipid peroxide radicals.
  • Functions also include maintaining membrane stability, influencing cell signaling, and modulating the activities of certain enzymes.
  • Exists in different natural and synthetic forms, but only the natural d-α-tocopherol is most potent biologically.

Mechanism of Action

  • Acts as a chain-breaking antioxidant: captures free radicals in membranes and lipoproteins, especially polyunsaturated fatty acids.
  • The intermediate tocopheroxyl radical is relatively stable and can be recycled back to tocopherol by Vitamin C.
  • This antioxidant network (Vitamin E + Vitamin C + glutathione) maintains Vitamin E in its active, reduced state.

Absorption and Metabolism

  • Absorbed with dietary fat and packaged in chylomicrons, then delivered to the liver.
  • Transported in plasma via α-tocopherol transfer protein, which inserts Vitamin E into very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL).
  • The RDA for Vitamin E in adults is about 15 mg/day.
  • It is abundant in vegetable oils (sunflower, safflower, wheat germ oil), nuts, meats, and small amounts in fruits and vegetables.
  • Higher intake may be required in diets rich in polyunsaturated fats.

Vitamin E Deficiency causes

  • Severe fat malabsorption (e.g., celiac disease, cystic fibrosis, chronic liver disease, prolonged cholestasis).
  • Genetic defect in α-tocopherol transfer protein.
  • Abetalipoproteinemia → impaired absorption and transport of Vitamin E.
  • Premature infants (inadequate stores at birth).

Clinical manifestations of vitamin E deficiency:

  • Neurological: degeneration of large myelinated axons → posterior column and spinocerebellar tract involvement → ataxia, areflexia, loss of vibration and position sense, peripheral neuropathy.
  • Ocular and muscular: ophthalmoplegia, skeletal myopathy, pigmentary retinopathy.
  • Hematologic: hemolytic anemia due to fragile RBC membranes from lipid peroxidation.

Explanations of other options:

Impaired hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during collagen synthesis (Option A): Suggestive of vitamin C deficiency.

Inability to carry out γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors (Option C): Consistent with vitamin K deficiency.

Impaired function of thymidylate synthase (Option D): Seen in folic acid deficiency which causes megaloblastic anemia and no neurological symptoms.

choices.text: Hydroxylation of proline residues during collagen formation
Decarboxylation of glutamate to γ-aminobutyric acid
γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors
Reduction of ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides by ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: A 42-year-old man undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis develops progressive irritability, painful tingling in his hands and feet, and recurrent seizures. On examination, he has peripheral neuropathy and pallor. Bone marrow examination reveals the following finding. Which of the following enzyme reactions is most directly impaired in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely underlying etiology causing peripheral neuropathy, recurrent seizures, pallor and ringed sideroblasts on bone marrow examination in a patient on isoniazid is Vitamin B6 deficiency which leads to impaired decarboxylation of glutamate to γ-aminobutyric acid

Vitamin B6

  • Refers to a group of compounds: pyridoxine, pyridoxal, and pyridoxamine, along with their 5′-phosphate derivatives.
  • The active form is pyridoxal 5′-phosphate (PLP), a coenzyme for over 100 enzymes.
  • About 80% of body stores are in muscle, bound to glycogen phosphorylase.

Functions

  • Amino acid metabolism:
    • Transamination, decarboxylation, and transsulfuration reactions
    • Conversion of tryptophan → niacin.
    • Homocysteine → cystathionine.
    • Heme synthesis: cofactor for δ-aminolevulinate synthase (first step).
    • Glycogen metabolism: PLP binds to glycogen phosphorylase.
    • Neurotransmitter synthesis: required for GABA, serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine.
    • Steroid hormone action: PLP regulates interaction of hormone-receptor complexes with DNA.

Deficiency

  • Causes: rare in healthy individuals; may occur in alcoholics, malabsorption, infants, or with drugs (isoniazid, hydralazine, penicillamine, cycloserine, L-dopa).
  • Pyridoxine is given along with isoniazid to prevent neuropathy.

Features:

  • Neurological: peripheral neuropathy, irritability, seizures, abnormal EEG.
  • Hematological: microcytic hypochromic (sideroblastic) anemia (↓ heme synthesis).
  • Dermatological: epithelial changes, glossitis.
  • Psychiatric: depression, confusion.
  • Infants: diarrhea, seizures, anemia.

Diagnosis

  • Based on low plasma PLP (<20 nmol/L).
  • Functional test: erythrocyte transaminase activity ↑ when PLP added in vitro.

Explanation of other options:

Hydroxylation of proline residues during collagen formation (Option A): This is consistent with Vitamin C deficiency.

γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in clotting factors (Option C): This is seen in Vitamin K deficiency.

Reduction of ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides by ribonucleotide reductase (Option D): Ribonucleotide reductase is a metalloenzyme containing iron.

choices.text: Erythrocyte transaminase activity
Erythrocyte transketolase activity
Ames assay
Erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: A 48-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with confusion, unsteady gait, and abnormal eye movements. His diet has been poor, and he often skips meals. Which of the following enzyme activities is considered a functional assay of the most likely deficient vitamin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely deficient vitamin this patient who is a chronic alcoholic who has presented with confusion, ataxia, and abnormal eye movements is vitamin B1 (thiamine) and its functional status can be assessed using erythrocyte transketolase activity.

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

  • Active form: Thiamine diphosphate (TPP), a coenzyme for oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoacids and branched-chain amino acids.
  • Key enzyme complexes requiring TPP:
    • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (links glycolysis to TCA cycle).
    • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle).
    • Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase (leucine, isoleucine, valine metabolism).
    • Transketolase (pentose phosphate pathway)
  • Thiamine triphosphate may also regulate nerve function by activating chloride channels.

Food Sources

  • Rich in yeast, organ meat, pork, legumes, beef, whole grains, and nuts.
  • Low in milled rice and processed grains → major cause of deficiency where polished rice is staple.
  • Destroyed by cooking, heat, and food processing.
  • Antithiamine factors: thiaminases (raw fish, shellfish) and polyhydroxyphenols (tea, coffee, betel nut, Brussels sprouts).

Clinical syndromes associated with deficiency:

  • Dry beriberi → symmetric peripheral neuropathy of motor and sensory nerves, diminished reflexes
  • Wet beriberi → high-output cardiac failure, tachycardia, edema, cardiomegaly.
  • Shoshin beriberi → acute, fulminant heart failure with metabolic acidosis.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy → nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confusion.
  • Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome → Wernicke features plus memory loss and confabulation.
  • Biochemical consequence: impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA → buildup of pyruvate/lactate → lactic acidosis (especially with high-carb intake).

Diagnosis

  • Best test: Erythrocyte transketolase activity before and after thiamine pyrophosphate addition.
  • > 25% increase = deficiency (activity coefficient >1.25).
  • Thiamine or phosphorylated esters can also be measured directly by HPLC.

Explanation of other options:

Erythrocyte transaminase activity (Option A): Vitamin B6 status is assessed by estimating erythrocyte transaminase activity.

Ames assay (Option C): The Ames assay uses a specially engineered strain of Salmonella typhimurium to identify mutagenic compounds. Since many carcinogens act as mutagens, detection of mutagenicity through this assay suggests possible carcinogenic potential.

Erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity (Option D): It is used to assess riboflavin (Vitamin B2) activity.

0.8
0.85
1.0

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has been on a strict ketogenic diet for 3 months, consisting primarily of fats with minimal carbohydrates. She reports fatigue during exercise but denies any respiratory symptoms. Indirect calorimetry is performed to evaluate her metabolic fuel utilization. Her respiratory quotient (RQ) is found to be close to the typical value seen with predominant fat metabolism. What is the expected RQ value in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The expected respiratory quotient in this patient on a diet primary consisting of fats is 0.7.

Respiratory Quotient (RQ) and Metabolic States

  • After a meal (fed state), caloric intake exceeds immediate energy needs. Excess calories are stored as glycogen and lipid.
  • Oxidation of substrates consumes oxygen and produces carbon dioxide. The ratio of CO₂ produced to O₂ consumed is called the respiratory quotient (RQ).

RQ values for different fuels:

  • Carbohydrates → 1.0 (Option D ruled out)
  • Proteins → 0.81 (Option B ruled out)
  • Fats → 0.71
  • Alcohol → 0.66

Fed state (especially after a carbohydrate-rich meal):

  • Carbohydrate oxidation predominates.
  • RQ approaches 1.0.
  • Over a 24-hour period on a mixed diet, average RQ is around 0.85, reflecting the combined oxidation of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. (Option C ruled out)
  • In fasting, carbohydrate oxidation decreases, fat oxidation increases, and RQ shifts downward toward 0.7.
  • Storage of excess calories as glycogen and fat requires energy, contributing to the thermic effect of food, which accounts for about 10% of daily energy expenditure.

choices.text: Impaired function of alcohol dehydrogenase
Selenosis
Kashin-Beck disease
Alkali disease

questions.text: A 19-year-old male from China presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and shortness of breath on exertion. Examination shows tachycardia and features of cardiomyopathy. Laboratory evaluation rules out viral myocarditis and ischemic disease. He is diagnosed with Keshan disease. Which of the following is another manifestation that might be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely manifestation that might be seen in this patient diagnosed with Keshan disease, which arises secondary to selenium deficiency, is Kashin-Beck disease.

  • Selenium, in the form of selenocysteine, is a key component of enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase, which protects proteins, membranes, lipids, and nucleic acids by breaking down hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.
  • This prevents oxidative damage to hemoglobin and cell structures. It is also required for deiodinase enzymes, which convert thyroxine (T4) into the active hormone triiodothyronine (T3).
  • Dietary selenium is mainly obtained from seafood, meat, and cereals, although its content in crops depends on soil concentration.

Deficiency

  • Keshan disease: An endemic cardiomyopathy seen in selenium-deficient areas of China, particularly in children and young women.
  • Kashin-Beck disease: An osteoarticular disorder with epiphyseal damage and deforming arthropathy, linked to selenium and iodine deficiency, which worsens oxidative stress in chondrocytes. Kashin-Beck disease shows a characteristic geographical pattern, mainly affecting farming areas in eastern Siberia, northern Korea, and central China.
  • Low selenium also aggravates cretinism when combined with iodine deficiency.

Toxicity

  • Chronic excess intake leads to selenosis, marked by hair and nail brittleness, loss, skin rash, irritability, neurological abnormalities, and a garlic-like odor to the breath. (Option B ruled out)
  • Historically, in livestock, high-selenium forages caused alkali disease in the American Great Plains. (Option D ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Impaired function of alcohol dehydrogenease (Option A): It is a metalloenzyme containing zinc.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/38757132/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK216723/

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3080494/

choices.text: Copper
Cobalt
Manganese
Molybdenum

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with recurrent seizures, developmental delay, and progressive neurological deterioration. Urine analysis reveals high levels of sulfite, and further studies demonstrate deficiency of sulfite oxidase. Deficiency of which trace metal is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sulfite oxidase is an iron and molybdenum containing metalloenzyme.

Molybdenum

Molybdenum is a key part of the universal cofactor molybdopterin, acting as a catalytic prosthetic group in several oxidase enzymes:

  • Xanthine oxidase (hypoxanthine → xanthine → uric acid)
  • Aldehyde oxidase (broad substrate detoxification, similar to cytochrome P450 system)
  • Sulfite oxidase (sulfite → sulfate)

Catalytic function:

  • The metal cycles between +4, +5, and +6 oxidation states, enabling transfer of electrons in these enzyme reactions.
  • Sulfite oxidase, for instance, uses Fe-Mo metalloenzyme activity to move electrons via cytochrome c.

Deficiency:

  • Caused by mutations in MOCS1, MOCS2, or GPHN genes, leading to defective molybdopterin
  • Results in sulfite oxidase deficiency, where sulfur-containing amino acids (cysteine, methionine) cannot be metabolized.
  • This leads to accumulation of toxic derivatives in neonates, causing severe deformities, brain damage, intractable seizures, profound developmental delay, and early death.

Explanation of other options:

Copper (Option A): Copper is a vital cofactor for nearly 30 human metalloenzymes, such as cytochrome oxidase, dopamine β-hydroxylase, tyrosinase, the cytosolic Cu-Zn superoxide dismutase, and lysyl oxidase. It is not a component of sulfite oxidase.

Cobalt (Option B): The main function of dietary cobalt is as the central atom in 5′-deoxyadenosylcobalamin (vitamin B12). Within this cofactor, cobalt in the +3 oxidation state is positioned in a corrin ring, where it facilitates the transfer of one-carbon groups such as methyl or methylene. In humans, this is crucial for the transfer of a methyl group from tetrahydrofolate to homocysteine to form methionine, as well as for the conversion of methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA during the breakdown of propionate derived from isoleucine and odd-chain fatty acids.

Manganese (Option C): Manganese is required for only a limited number of enzymes in humans, most of which are located in the mitochondria. These include isocitrate dehydrogenase of the TCA cycle, glutamate synthetase and arginase involved in nitrogen metabolism, and the gluconeogenic enzymes pyruvate carboxylase and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase, along with isopropyl malate synthase and mitochondrial superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD).

choices.text: Flushing, itching, and hyperglycemia
Severe sensory neuropathy
Increased intracranial pressure with headache
Burning feet syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl from a rural village presents with progressive difficulty seeing at night. On physical examination, the following finding is noted. If this child were instead to consume excess amounts of the vitamin which is deficient, which of the following clinical features would most likely develop?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The vitamin deficient in this child with difficulty seeing at night and examination revealing phrynoderma is vitamin A and in excess, it can cause Increased intracranial pressure with headache.

  • Vitamin A refers to retinol and retinyl esters, with metabolites like retinaldehyde and retinoic acid also biologically active.
  • Retinal (11-cis) is vital for vision, while retinoic acid regulates cell growth, differentiation, and gene expression through retinoid receptors (RARs, RXRs).
  • The vitamin exists as preformed retinyl esters and provitamin A carotenoids (mainly β-carotene) in the diet.
  • The liver stores about 90% of body reserves and releases vitamin A bound to retinol-binding protein, ensuring safe transport and uptake. Retinoids also influence immunity, iron utilization, and cell-mediated defenses.

Deficiency

  • Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of preventable blindness globally. Early signs include reduced sensitivity to green light, progressing to night blindness, and later xerophthalmia with corneal keratinization, which can cause blindness.
  • Clinical features include Bitot's spots, conjunctival dryness, and keratomalacia.
  • Deficiency also impairs immune responses, increasing vulnerability to infections, especially in children, and contributes to higher mortality rates in undernourished populations and during pregnancy.
  • Cutaneous manifestations include xerosis, scaling, dermomalacia and phrynoderma.
  • Phrynoderma which presents as rough, keratotic follicular papules that typically affect the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms but may also spread to the extensor areas of the limbs, shoulders, back, posterior neck, and abdomen, giving a "toad-like" appearance.
  • While often linked to vitamin A deficiency, it is not specific to it and can also occur with deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and even zinc.

Toxicity

  • Excess vitamin A overwhelms binding proteins, leading to free vitamin A-induced tissue damage.
  • Acute toxicity manifests with increased intracranial pressure, nausea, headache, vertigo, seizures, and exfoliative dermatitis, which may be fatal.
  • Chronic toxicity presents with dry skin, alopecia, cheilosis, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, hypercalcemia, bone pain, amenorrhea, pseudotumor cerebri, and liver fibrosis.
  • In pregnancy, excess vitamin A or retinoid exposure can cause teratogenic effects such as craniofacial and cardiac malformations.
  • High-dose β-carotene is generally non-toxic but may cause carotenemia (yellowing of skin) and has been linked to adverse effects in smokers.

Explanations of other options:

Flushing, itching, and hyperglycemia (Option A): Describes features seen in niacin toxicity.

Severe sensory neuropathy (Option B): Seen in Vitamin B6 toxicity. Peripheral neuropathy is also seen in vitamin B6 deficiency.

Burning feet syndrome (Option D): Associated with pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency.

choices.text: Arises due to mutation in ATP7A gene
Copper deficiency impairs cytochrome c oxidase and dopamine β-hydroxylase activity
Copper histidine therapy may be beneficial if started early
Deficiency of copper prevents proper functioning of lysyl hydroxylase

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with developmental delay, seizures, and recurrent episodes of hypothermia. His parents report that his hair has become sparse, brittle, depigmented, and twisted as shown. Examination shows hypotonia, failure to thrive, and hypopigmented skin. Laboratory investigations reveal low serum copper and ceruloplasmin. Which of the following statements regarding the underlying defect in this condition is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of developmental delay, seizures, and recurrent episodes of hypothermia along with depigmented hair, along with low serum copper and ceruloplasmin is Menkes disease, in which deficiency of copper prevents proper functioning of lysyl oxidase, causing defective collagen cross-linking.

  • Menkes disease, also called kinky hair disease, is an X-linked recessive neurodegenerative disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase. (Option A ruled out)
  • The defect leads to impaired intestinal absorption and transport of copper, resulting in low serum copper and ceruloplasmin.
  • The shortage of copper disrupts the function of multiple copper-dependent enzymes such as superoxide dismutase, cytochrome c oxidase, and dopamine β-hydroxylase. (Option B ruled out)
  • Symptoms appear within the first months of life and include hypothermia, hypotonia, seizures, and distinctive facial features with chubby cheeks and brittle, kinky, depigmented hair.
  • Hair microscopy often reveals trichorrhexis nodosa and pili torti.
  • Affected children also experience feeding difficulties, severe developmental delay, vascular tortuosity, and optic atrophy.
  • Neuropathological changes include degeneration of cerebral gray matter and Purkinje cell loss in the cerebellum.
  • Without treatment, death typically occurs by age three. Rarely, females may present with milder disease.
  • Copper histidine injections may slow neurological decline if started very early, especially in infants with residual copper transport activity. (Option C ruled out)
  • The clinical manifestations also stem from deficient lysyl oxidase, a copper-dependent enzyme essential for collagen cross-linking.

choices.text: Autoimmune β-cell destruction with absolute insulin deficiency
Reduced cellular response to insulin at muscle and adipose tissue
Inherited LDL receptor defect causing impaired cholesterol clearance
Mutation in glucokinase gene impairing hepatic glucose sensing

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with marked central obesity has come for a routine checkup. On examination, the following finding is seen. Her blood tests reveal fasting glucose of 118 mg/dL, triglycerides of 210 mg/dL, and HDL of 32 mg/dL. Blood pressure is 148/92 mmHg. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the laboratory parameters and the finding of acanthosis nigricans is metabolic syndrome which arises due to reduced cellular response to insulin at muscle and adipose tissue.

  • Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of metabolic abnormalities that heightens the risk of cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes.
  • It is characterized by central obesity, elevated triglycerides, reduced HDL cholesterol, hyperglycemia, and hypertension.

Risk Factors

  • Overweight/Obesity - A strong driver, with visceral fat central to insulin resistance.
  • Sedentary Lifestyle - Physical inactivity worsens adiposity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and hyperglycemia. Prolonged screen time (>4 h/day) doubles the risk.
  • Genetics - Multiple variants contribute; heritability of traits exceeds 50%.
  • Aging - Nearly half of U.S. adults >60 years are affected, with women more commonly impacted.

Associated Conditions

  • Diabetes Mellitus - ~75% of patients with type 2 diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance have metabolic syndrome.
  • Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) - Patients are twice as likely to die from CVD; risk of heart disease and stroke is markedly higher.
  • Lipodystrophy - Both genetic and acquired forms are strongly linked to insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

Etiology & Pathophysiology

  • Central Role of Insulin Resistance - Impaired insulin action leads to hyperinsulinemia and hyperglycemia.
  • Fatty Acids - Excess circulating free fatty acids from adipose tissue drive insulin resistance, impair glucose uptake, and promote lipid accumulation in liver and muscle.
  • Leptin Resistance - Reduced leptin action worsens appetite control and insulin sensitivity.
  • Adipokines & Inflammation - Dysregulated adipokines (adiponectin ↓, resistin ↑, TNF-α ↑) promote systemic insulin resistance and vascular dysfunction.
  • Gut Microbiome - Altered bacterial composition may contribute to metabolic dysfunction.

Metabolic Abnormalities

  • Waist Circumference - Strong marker of risk, though precise measurement methods vary.
  • Glucose Intolerance - Impaired suppression of hepatic glucose output, progressing to type 2 diabetes.
  • Hypertension - Related to insulin resistance, sodium retention, and vascular dysfunction.
  • Dyslipidemia - Elevated triglycerides and low HDL levels increase atherosclerotic risk.
  • Proinflammatory Cytokines - IL-6, TNF-α, and others amplify systemic inflammation.

Clinical Features

  • Common associations include acanthosis nigricans, fatty liver disease, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), and hyperuricemia.
  • Strong links to atherosclerosis, myocardial infarction, stroke, and Alzheimer's disease.

Explanations of other options:

Autoimmune β-cell destruction with absolute insulin deficiency (Option A): Describes type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. The presence of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and central obesity is more suggestive of metabolic syndrome.

Inherited LDL receptor defect causing impaired cholesterol clearance (Option C): Explains pathogenesis of familial hypercholesterolemia which usually presents with elevated LDL and normal triglyceride levels.

Mutation in glucokinase gene (Option D): Leads to MODY (Maturity onset diabetes of young)

choices.text: Pyruvate carboxylase
Succinate dehydrogenase
Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase
Transketolase

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with painful cracks at the corners of his mouth, a magenta-colored tongue, and burning, itchy eyes with photophobia. On examination, the following findings are noted. His diet mainly consists of polished rice, with little milk or green vegetables. Which of the following enzymes will be most directly impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely deficient vitamin in this patient is riboflavin (Vitamin B2) which is required for the enzyme succinate dehydrogenase.

  • Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is an essential nutrient that functions as a coenzyme in energy metabolism, primarily in the form of flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).
  • These cofactors participate in numerous oxidation-reduction reactions, including those in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, fatty acid and amino acid oxidation, and the mitochondrial respiratory chain.
  • Enzymes that require riboflavin, known as flavoenzymes, include succinate dehydrogenase, monoamine oxidase, and glutathione reductase.
  • FAD also plays a role in regulating homocysteine metabolism through methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase and is important in drug and steroid metabolism.
  • Riboflavin deficiency, though uncommon, is usually due to inadequate dietary intake.
  • Clinical signs include inflammation and lesions of the lips and tongue (cheilosis, glossitis), seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and sometimes anemia and mood changes.
  • Laboratory diagnosis is typically made by assessing erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity with and without added FAD.
  • Riboflavin deficiency is rarely fatal because the body conserves it efficiently and can recycle it from degraded enzymes.
  • Major dietary sources include milk, dairy products, enriched cereals, meats, eggs, legumes, and green vegetables.
  • Riboflavin is highly light-sensitive, so proper storage of foods like milk is important to prevent its loss. Notably, riboflavin has no established toxicity, as excess is excreted in the urine.

Explanations of other options:

Pyruvate carboxylase (Option A): The coenzyme for pyruvate carboxylase is biotin.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (Option C): Vitamin B12 acts as the coenzyme for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase

Transketolase (Option D): The active form of Vitamin B1 functions as the coenzyme for transketolase.

choices.text: Hydroxylation of lysine residues in collagen fibrils
γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in bone matrix proteins
Activation of alkaline phosphatase in osteoblasts
Conversion of 25-hydroxy vitamin D to calcitriol in the kidney

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation is on long-term warfarin therapy. She presents with diffuse bone pain and a recent low-impact vertebral fracture. Her coagulation profile shows prolonged PT/INR, consistent with the effect of her medication. Bone biopsy reveals impaired calcium binding by osteocalcin, despite normal dietary calcium intake and vitamin D status. Which of the following biochemical processes is most likely inhibited in this patient due to her treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely biochemical process inhibited in this patient on warfarin therapy is γ-carboxylation of glutamate residues in bone matrix proteins due to inhibition of Vitamin K.

Role of Vitamin K

  • Essential for the synthesis of blood-clotting proteins 2, 7, 9, 10
  • Antagonists like dicumarol and warfarin are used therapeutically to reduce coagulation.

Forms of Vitamin K

  • Phylloquinone - primary dietary form from green vegetables
  • Menaquinones - produced by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione and derivatives - synthetic forms convertible to phylloquinone.

Biochemical Function

  • Acts as a coenzyme for carboxylation of glutamate residues in proteins, producing γ-carboxyglutamate (GLA).
  • This modification allows proteins to bind calcium and anchor to membranes.
  • The process involves a cycle: hydroquinone → epoxide → quinone → hydroquinone, regulated by warfarin-sensitive reductases.
  • High doses of vitamin K can counteract warfarin overdose.

Targets of Vitamin K Action

  • Clotting factors: Prothrombin (II), VII, IX, X, and proteins C & S. These contain multiple GLA residues essential for calcium binding and function.
  • Bone and tissue proteins: Osteocalcin, matrix Gla protein, nephrocalcin, and Gas6-important in bone strength, vascular biology, nervous system regulation, and apoptosis.

Deficiency

  • Leads to impaired synthesis of vitamin K-dependent proteins in blood, bone, lung, kidney, and placenta.
  • Common causes: reduced intake, malabsorption, broad-spectrum antibiotics, chronic liver disease, or bile salt deficiency.
  • In newborns, deficiency can cause hemorrhagic disease; prevented by routine neonatal vitamin K administration.
  • Laboratory clue: prolonged prothrombin time (PT) is an early indicator.

Management

  • Mild deficiency: treated with low doses of vitamin K (oral or IV).
  • Severe deficiency/anticoagulant reversal: higher doses, fresh frozen plasma (FFP), or prothrombin complex concentrates (PCC).
  • Vitamin K administration must be balanced in patients requiring anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic risk.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hydroxylation of lysine residues in collagen fibrils (Option A): Incorrect. This is a vitamin C-dependent step in collagen maturation, not affected by warfarin.
  • Activation of alkaline phosphatase in osteoblasts (Option C): Incorrect. ALP activity relates to matrix mineralization and phosphate handling; it is not vitamin K-dependent.
  • Conversion of 25-hydroxy vitamin D to calcitriol (Option D): Incorrect. This renal 1α-hydroxylation depends on PTH and kidney function, not on vitamin K/warfarin.

choices.text: Folic acid deficiency
Vitamin B12 deficiency
Iron deficiency anemia
Vitamin C deficiency

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with fatigue, glossitis, and tingling in his feet. He follows a strict vegan diet. Examination shows pallor and impaired vibration sense in the lower limbs. Blood tests reveal:
Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL
MCV: 112 fL
Peripheral smear: hypersegmented neutrophils
Serum homocysteine: ↑ elevated
Serum methylmalonic acid: ↑ elevated
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient with a strict vegan diet, glossitis, neurological symptoms, hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear, and elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid is vitamin B12 deficiency.

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) has a cobalt atom within a corrin ring. Exists in several forms:

  • Adenosylcobalamin (mitochondrial, cofactor for methylmalonyl-CoA mutase).
  • Methylcobalamin (cytoplasmic, cofactor for methionine synthase).
  • Hydroxocobalamin (present in small amounts; rapidly interconverted).

Sources & Requirements

  • Synthesized only by microorganisms.
  • Humans obtain it mainly from animal products (meat, fish, dairy).
  • Plant foods lack cobalamin unless contaminated by bacteria.

Absorption

Two pathways:

1. Passive - throughout intestine, inefficient (<1%).

2. Active - in ileum, requires intrinsic factor (IF).

  • Dietary B12 is released from food proteins by gastric enzymes and binds haptocorrins (HCs).
  • In intestine, HCs are degraded, and cobalamin transfers to IF, secreted by gastric parietal cells.
  • The IF-B12 complex binds cubilin receptors in the ileum for absorption.
  • Absorbed B12 enters blood bound to transcobalamin II (TC II).
  • Enterohepatic circulation helps maintain levels; deficiency develops faster in malabsorption than in vegans.

Clinical Features of Deficiency

  • General: Anemia, anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea/constipation.
  • Oral: Glossitis, angular cheilosis.
  • Severe cases: Jaundice, fever, hyperpigmentation.
  • Hematology: Macrocytosis, megaloblastic anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia.
  • Neurological: Peripheral neuropathy, cognitive changes, impaired proprioception, psychiatric symptoms.
  • Infections: Increased susceptibility (respiratory, urinary).

Hematologic Findings

  • Peripheral blood: Macrocytic anemia with anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, hypersegmented neutrophils.
  • Bone marrow: Hypercellular, megaloblastic changes, increased early erythroid precursors, possible myelodysplasia-like appearance.

Causes of Deficiency

1. Inadequate intake: Seen in strict vegans or severe malnutrition.

2. Malabsorption:

  • Gastric causes: Pernicious anemia (autoimmune IF deficiency), gastrectomy, congenital IF defects.
  • Intestinal causes: Ileal resection, Crohn's, tropical sprue, fish tapeworm, celiac disease, HIV infection, radiation injury.
  • Pancreatic disease: Failure to release cobalamin from HC.
  • Genetic defects: Cubilin/TC II abnormalities.

3. Abnormal metabolism

  • Congenital methylmalonic acidemia/acidemia.
  • Nitrous oxide toxicity (inactivates methylcobalamin).

4. Pernicious Anemia (PA): Common autoimmune cause of severe deficiency, especially in older adults of Northern European descent.

Diagnosis:

  • Both serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine levels are elevated in vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Serum cobalamin levels can be measured using ELIZA

Explanation of other options:

Folic acid deficiency (Option A): Serum homocysteine levels are elevated but not methylmalonic acid. There are no neurological symptoms.

Iron deficiency anemia (Option C): Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. Homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels are not elevated.

Vitamin C deficiency (Option D): Leads to clinical features like inflamed and bleeding gums, perifollicular hemorrhages, and poor wound healing.

choices.text: Enzymes lower the activation energy by stabilizing the transition state
Enzymes increase the equilibrium constant (Keq) by favoring product formation
Enzymes accelerate the rate at which equilibrium is reached
Enzymes do not alter the overall Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of a reaction

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being treated with a novel antiviral drug that acts by inhibiting a viral protease. The drug mimics the transition state of the normal substrate, binding the enzyme tightly and preventing catalysis. Which of the following statements about enzyme action is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enzymes do not change the equilibrium constant (Keq).

Biomedical Importance of Enzyme Kinetics

  • Enzymes regulate essential biochemical processes, and balanced activity is required for homeostasis.
  • Enzyme kinetics measures how fast enzyme-catalyzed reactions occur and what factors influence them.
  • Clinical uses include diagnosing disease through abnormal enzyme levels (e.g., in myocardial infarction, prostate cancer, or liver injury).
  • Because enzymes are central to nearly all physiological pathways, they are also key drug targets.

Chemical Reactions and Equilibrium

  • Reactions are described using balanced equations, showing substrates and products in correct proportions.
  • Reversibility is a fundamental property of chemical reactions; many reactions in cells are functionally irreversible because products are quickly removed.
  • The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) determines whether a reaction proceeds forward or backward.
  • Negative ΔG → reaction is spontaneous.
  • Positive ΔG → unfavorable unless coupled with other processes.

Rates of Reactions

  • Reaction speed depends on the activation energy barrier (ΔG‡) that must be overcome to form a transition state.
  • The transition state is a high-energy intermediate between reactants and products.
  • The rate of reaction increases when more molecules have sufficient kinetic energy to reach this state.
  • The free energy, activation energy, and transition state are shown with an example in the image below.

Factors affecting rate:

  • Temperature: increases kinetic energy and collision frequency.
  • Concentration: higher concentrations increase collision probability.
  • Collision theory: molecules must collide with proper orientation and energy.

Reaction Orders and Rate Constants

  • The rate law describes how reaction rate depends on concentrations of reactants.
  • Reactions can be first-order, second-order, or higher, depending on how many molecules
  • The rate constant (k) is characteristic of a given reaction under set conditions.
  • At equilibrium, the ratio of forward and backward rate constants equals the equilibrium constant (Keq).

Enzyme Catalysis

  • Enzymes lower activation energy by stabilizing the transition state, not by altering ΔG of the overall reaction. (Options A and D ruled out)
  • Mechanisms include:
    • Acid-base catalysis (proton transfer)
    • Electrostatic stabilization by charged groups or metals
    • Steric effects that position substrates properly.
    • Some enzymes use covalent catalysis, where a temporary covalent bond forms with the substrate.

Note: HIV protease stabilizes transition states; serine proteases like chymotrypsin form covalent intermediates.

Enzymes and Equilibrium

  • Enzymes do not affect equilibrium constants (Keq)
  • They accelerate how quickly equilibrium is reached by lowering ΔG‡, but the final ratio of substrates to products is unchanged. (Option C ruled out)
  • This is because Keq depends only on the free energy of initial and final states, not on the catalytic pathway.

choices.text: Succinate dehydrogenase - Biotin
Pyruvate dehydrogenase - Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
Lactate dehydrogenase - Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP)
Glutamate dehydrogenase - Vitamin C

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme-cofactor pairs is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the correctly matched enzyme-cofactor pair is pyruvate dehydrogenase - Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP).

Pyruvate Oxidation: Link Between Glycolysis and the Citric Acid Cycle

  • Pyruvate, formed in glycolysis, is transported into mitochondria via a symporter.
  • It undergoes irreversible oxidative decarboxylation to form acetyl-CoA, catalyzed by the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH complex).
  • This multi-enzyme system is analogous to the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex and is located near the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Structure and Function of the PDH Complex

  • The reaction begins with pyruvate being decarboxylated by the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) enzyme, producing a hydroxyethyl intermediate bound to thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP).
  • This intermediate is transferred to dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2), where it reacts with lipoamide to generate acetyl-lipoamide. Coenzyme A then forms acetyl-CoA from this intermediate.
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) reoxidizes reduced lipoamide using FAD, which is in turn reoxidized by NAD⁺, producing NADH.

The overall reaction is:

Pyruvate + NAD⁺ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H⁺ + CO₂

  • The complex keeps intermediates channeled between enzymes, enhancing efficiency and preventing side reactions.

Regulation of PDH

  • End-product inhibition: Acetyl-CoA and NADH inhibit the enzyme.
  • Covalent modification: Phosphorylation by a specific kinase (stimulated by high ATP, NADH, or acetyl-CoA) inactivates PDH.
  • Dephosphorylation by a phosphatase (stimulated by ADP, pyruvate, and insulin) activates it.
  • PDH activity is reduced in energy-rich states and increased during fasting or when fatty acids are oxidized, ensuring balanced energy metabolism.

Clinical Aspects

  • Lactic acidosis occurs when PDH is inhibited, leading to pyruvate buildup and its conversion to lactate.
  • Inhibitors: Arsenic and mercury ions block the -SH groups of lipoic acid, preventing normal function.
  • Thiamine (vitamin B₁) deficiency impairs PDH activity and can cause severe lactic acidosis; this is common in alcoholism due to poor diet and reduced thiamine absorption.
  • Inherited PDH deficiency (mutations in PDH complex enzymes) leads to lactic acidosis, especially after glucose intake, and often causes neurological problems since the brain depends heavily on glucose metabolism.

Explanation of other options:

Succinate dehydrogenase - Biotin (Option A): Succinate dehyrogenase uses FAD, not biotin.

Lactate dehydrogenase - Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) (Option C): Lactate dehydrogenase used NADH as a cofactor.

Glutamate dehydrogenase - Vitamin C (Option D): Glutamate dehydrogenase can use either NAD+ or NADP+.

4
6
