questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents with nausea, vomiting, and Kussmaul breathing. His labs show:

1. Blood glucose: 58 mg/dL
2. Ketone bodies: markedly elevated
3. Arterial blood gas: metabolic acidosis

In the fasting state, his liver attempts to restore blood glucose by gluconeogenesis. How many molecules of ATP and GTP together are required to synthesize one molecule of glucose from two molecules of pyruvate via gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stepwise requirement:
    • Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate (pyruvate carboxylase) → 2 ATP
    • Oxaloacetate → PEP (PEP carboxykinase) → 2 GTP
    • 3-phosphoglycerate → 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (3-PG kinase) → 2 ATP
  • Total = 4 ATP + 2 GTP = 6 high-energy bonds

This energy demand is why gluconeogenesis is suppressed unless absolutely required (e.g., fasting, DKA, starvation).

choices.text: It increases the maximum velocity (Vmax) of alcohol dehydrogenase
It competitively inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing methanol metabolism
It irreversibly binds alcohol dehydrogenase, leading to enzyme inactivation
It activates aldehyde dehydrogenase to accelerate methanol clearance

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after consuming homemade alcohol. He is confused and has severe abdominal pain and visual disturbances. He is suspected of methanol poisoning and is started on intravenous ethanol therapy. Which of the following best explains the mechanism by which ethanol acts as an antidote in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ethanol acts as a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing methanol metabolism.

  • Enzyme inhibitors are valuable both in research and therapy.
  • Their effectiveness depends on various molecular interactions (hydrogen bonds, hydrophobic interactions, electrostatics, van der Waals).
  • They can be classified based on site of action, chemical modification of enzyme, or kinetic effects.
  • Two main kinetic categories:
  1. Inhibition that can be overcome by raising substrate concentration - competitive (Option C ruled out)
  2. Inhibition that cannot be overcome in this way - noncompetitive

Competitive Inhibition

  • Mimics the substrate and binds to the active site.
  • Prevents substrate from binding by occupying its place. (Option D ruled out)
  • Example: Malonate inhibits succinate dehydrogenase by competing with succinate.
  • Effects: Vmax unchanged (can still be reached if enough substrate is added), while Km increases (requires higher substrate concentration). (Option A ruled out)
  • Lineweaver-Burk plots: slope changes, intercept at 1/Vmax stays the same.

Noncompetitive Inhibition

  • Inhibitor binds to a different site (not the substrate-binding site).
  • Can bind enzyme whether or not substrate is already attached.
  • Effects: Vmax decreases (enzyme efficiency reduced), while Km remains unchanged (substrate affinity unaffected).
  • Lineweaver-Burk plots show altered y-intercept but same x-intercept.

Irreversible Inhibition

  • Inhibitors form covalent bonds or stable chemical modifications of essential residues.
  • These permanently inactivate the enzyme (enzyme is "poisoned").
  • Examples include inhibitors that attach to amino acid side chains critical for catalysis or structure.

Mechanism-Based (Suicide) Inhibition

  • Specialized inhibitors resembling substrates.
  • Bind to active site, where the enzyme's own catalytic action transforms them into a highly reactive compound.
  • This reactive form then covalently attaches to the enzyme, blocking a vital residue.
  • They are highly specific and only active within the enzyme's catalytic site, making them powerful and selective inhibitors.

choices.text: ATP acts as a positive allosteric effector on phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), accelerating glycolysis
ATP activates isocitrate dehydrogenase allosterically to increase flux through the TCA cycle
Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate binds allosterically to phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), enhancing glycolysis
Glucagon stimulates glycogen phosphorylase by phosphorylation, increasing glucose release

questions.text: A 28-year-old man runs a marathon after drinking a glucose-rich energy drink. During the final stretch, his muscle cells rapidly shift toward glycolysis to meet energy demands. In this situation, the rate of glycolysis is upregulated because of allosteric modulation of a key regulatory enzyme. Which of the following best explains this regulation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the allosteric modulation which upregulates glycolysis is binding of fructose-2,6-bisphosphate allosterically to PFK-1, enhancing glycolysis.

  • Enzyme activity can be regulated quickly by allosteric ligands or covalent modifications, while long-term regulation relies on protein synthesis.
  • Allosteric regulation allows rapid adaptation to changes in metabolic demand.

Allosteric Effectors

  • Small molecules that bind noncovalently to enzymes, forming enzyme-effector complexes with properties different from the enzyme alone.
  • Binding can either increase (activation) or decrease (inhibition) catalytic efficiency.
  • May also influence enzyme location, interactions with other proteins, or sensitivity to additional effectors.
  • Effectors often include metabolic intermediates or end products that act as regulatory ligands.

Properties of Allosteric Effectors

  • The term allosteric means "occupying another site," distinct from the active site.
  • Often do not resemble substrates of the enzyme.
  • Example: Serine acts as an effector of 3-phosphoglycerate dehydrogenase.
  • Allosteric enzymes alter activity by changing Km (K-series), Vmax (V-series), or both.

Types of Allosteric Effectors

  1. Feedback Effectors
    • Usually pathway end products.
    • Inhibit or activate enzymes controlling the first committed step of the pathway (feedback inhibition).
  2. Indicator Metabolites
    • Intermediates with broader roles beyond their own pathway.
    • Example: Citrate activates acetyl-CoA carboxylase in fatty acid synthesis; alanine inhibits pyruvate kinase.
  3. Second Messengers
    • Special effectors triggered by external signals like hormones or nerve impulses.
    • Examples: cAMP, cGMP, nitric oxide, Ca²⁺, inositol phosphates.
    • Regulate enzymes involved in processes such as muscle contraction and glycogen breakdown.

Model Example: Aspartate Transcarbamoylase (ATCase)

  • Key enzyme in pyrimidine biosynthesis.
  • Inhibited by CTP (end product, feedback inhibition).
  • Stimulated by ATP (indicator metabolite, balances purine and pyrimidine synthesis).

Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) Regulation

Activators (↑ activity)

  • Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate → most potent activator in liver, relieves ATP inhibition.
  • Fructose 6-phosphate → substrate-level activation.
  • AMP (5′-AMP)** → signals low energy, stimulates PFK-1.
  • Inorganic phosphate (Pi) → supports glycolysis.
  • Insulin → increases expression and activity of PFK-1 in fed state.

Inhibitors (↓ activity)

  • ATP → high energy charge suppresses enzyme activity.
  • Citrate → signals abundance of biosynthetic precursors (link with TCA cycle).
  • Glucagon → lowers fructose 2,6-bisphosphate via cAMP → inhibits PFK-1.
  • H+ ions (low pH, e.g., during lactic acidosis) → prevent excess glycolysis.

Hormonal Regulation

  • Insulin (fed state): ↑ fructose 2,6-bisphosphate → activates PFK-1.
  • Glucagon (fasting state): ↓ fructose 2,6-bisphosphate → inhibits PFK-1, favoring gluconeogenesis.

Explanation of other options:

ATP acts as a positive allosteric effector on phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), accelerating glycolysis (Option A): This is wrong since ATP as an allosteric inhibitor of PFK-1.

ATP activates isocitrate dehydrogenase allosterically to increase flux through the TCA cycle (Option B): This is a false statement as ATP inhibits isocitrate dehydrogenase allosterically.

Glucagon stimulates glycogen phosphorylase by phosphorylation, increasing glucose release (Option D): This is a true statement related to glycogen breakdown but an example of covalent modification.

choices.text: It increases enzyme affinity for glucose, making the reaction faster at low substrate concentrations
It decreases enzyme affinity for glucose, requiring a higher substrate concentration to reach half of Vmax
It functions as a non-competitive inhibitor
None of the above

questions.text: A 32-year-old researcher is studying the effect of a new antidiabetic drug on hepatic glucokinase activity. In the presence of the drug, the enzyme's Vmax remains unchanged, but the Km for glucose increases twofold. According to the Michaelis-Menten equation, which of the following best describes the drug's action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the Michaelis-Menten equation, the given drug decreases enzyme affinity for glucose, requiring a higher substrate concentration to reach half of Vmax

Michaelis-Menten Equation

Describes how initial reaction velocity (vi) depends on substrate concentration [S].

Formula: vi = (Vmax [S]) / (Km + [S])

Km = substrate concentration at which velocity is half of Vmax

Higher Km → lower affinity (need more substrate to achieve same rate). (Option A ruled out)

In this case, the Km is increasing and Vmax is unchanged, suggestive of competitive inhibition. (Option C ruled out)

Key situations:

  1. When [S] < Km → velocity is directly proportional to [S].
  2. When [S] > Km → velocity approaches Vmax and is independent of [S].
  3. When [S] = Km → velocity = ½ Vmax.

Linear Transformation (Lineweaver-Burk Plot)

  • Direct measurement of Vmax and Km is difficult at saturating [S].
  • Rearranging the equation gives a linear form: 1/vi = (Km/Vmax)(1/[S]) + 1/Vmax
  • This is plotted as 1/vi (y-axis) vs 1/[S] (x-axis).
  • Y-intercept = 1/Vmax
  • X-intercept = -1/Km
  • Slope = Km/Vmax

choices.text: Allosteric activation of glycogen phosphorylase by AMP
Phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase kinase, which in turn phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase
Dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase, leading to increased glycogenolysis
Direct proteolytic cleavage of glycogen phosphorylase into its active form

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the ER after a road traffic accident. He has severe blood loss and develops hypoglycemia. In response to the stress, epinephrine is released, leading to rapid mobilization of glucose from liver glycogen stores. Which of the following best explains the molecular mechanism by which epinephrine increases hepatic glycogen breakdown in this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The molecular mechanism by which epinephrine increases hepatic glycogen breakdown in this scenario is by phosphorylation of glycogen phosphorylase kinase, which in turn phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase. This is an example of covalent modification.

Covalent Modifications

  • Proteins can undergo many covalent modifications such as prenylation, glycosylation, hydroxylation, and fatty acylation, which provide unique structural features that last for the protein's lifetime.
  • The principle is that adding or removing a covalent bond alters the protein's properties, allowing regulation of function.
  • Covalent modifications are of two types - irreversible and reversible.

Irreversible Modifications

  • Partial proteolysis of precursor proteins (proproteins or zymogens) activates them permanently.
  • Once cleaved, the protein cannot revert to its inactive form.
  • Example: chymotrypsinogen → chymotrypsin via hydrolysis of peptide bonds.
  • Many digestive enzymes (trypsin, chymotrypsin, lipases, pepsin) and proteins in blood clotting and complement cascades are activated this way.

Reversible Modifications

  • Include acetylation, ADP-ribosylation, sumoylation, and phosphorylation.
  • "Reversible" refers to the ability to restore the protein to its precursor form by removing the modification.

Phosphorylation:

  • Involves serine, threonine, or tyrosine residues.
  • Protein kinases transfer phosphate groups from ATP.
  • Protein phosphatases remove phosphate groups. (dephosphorylation)
  • Phosphorylation changes enzyme activity by altering conformation and function.

Protein Acetylation

  • Involves adding an acetyl group to lysine residues.
  • Can directly regulate mitochondrial proteins by responding to acetyl-CoA levels.
  • Requires acetyltransferases and is reversed by deacetylases (histone deacetylases and sirtuins).
  • Acts as a sensor of cell energy state: high acetyl-CoA → increased acetylation; low acetyl-CoA → favors deacetylation.

Covalent Modifications and Metabolism

  • Phosphorylation and acetylation are powerful regulators of metabolic enzymes.
  • They function like allosteric control but work through covalent bond changes.
  • Allow rapid, specific adjustments of enzyme activity in response to metabolic needs.
  • Example enzymes regulated by phosphorylation include: acetyl-CoA carboxylase, glycogen synthase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, HMG-CoA reductase, glycogen phosphorylase, and citrate lyase.

Key Point

  • Reversible covalent modifications (phosphorylation, acetylation) provide flexibility and rapid adaptation.
  • Irreversible modifications (proteolysis) ensure permanent activation of enzymes when required, such as in digestion, blood clotting, and immune defense.

Explanations of other options:

Allosteric AMP activation (Option A): True for glycogen phosphorylase in muscle, but here the vignette is about hormonal regulation in liver.

Dephosphorylation of glycogen synthase (Option C): Activates glycogen synthesis, not breakdown.

Proteolytic cleavage (Option D): Selective proteolysis is seen in trypsinogen → trypsin, for example and is not relevant to glycogen phosphorylase.

choices.text: Sigmoid curve
Bell-shaped curve
Hyperbolic curve
Linear curve

questions.text: When enzyme activity is plotted against varying pH values, which type of curve is typically observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enzyme activity rises as pH approaches the optimum, then declines on either side when ionization of active site residues and substrates is altered, which produces a bell-shaped curve, with the peak at the enzyme's optimal pH.

Enzyme Catalysis

  • Enzymes lower the activation energy (ΔG‡), stabilizing transition states and thereby speeding up reactions.
  • Some use unique mechanisms, such as covalent catalysis, to form temporary enzyme-substrate bonds.

Equilibrium Constant (Keq)

  • At equilibrium, the rate of forward and reverse reactions becomes equal.
  • The equilibrium constant is defined as the ratio of the rate constants of the forward and reverse reactions.
  • Importantly, equilibrium represents a dynamic state, where reactants and products are constantly interconverted without net change.

Enzymes and Keq: Although enzymes alter reaction speed, they do not change the equilibrium constant (Keq) or the overall free energy difference (ΔG°). They only affect how quickly equilibrium is reached.

Temperature and Enzymes

  • Both uncatalyzed and enzyme-catalyzed reactions increase with temperature. However, excessive heat can disrupt noncovalent interactions, leading to denaturation and loss of function.
  • The temperature coefficient (Q10) describes the rate increase for a 10°C rise in temperature.

pH

  • Enzyme activity is strongly influenced by hydrogen ion concentration. Most enzymes function best in a specific pH range, and deviation can disrupt the charge states of amino acids involved in substrate binding or catalysis.
  • This alters enzyme activity, sometimes abolishing it completely.
  • The majority of intracellular enzymes function best within a pH range of 5 to 9, forming a bell-shaped curve as shown below.

Substrate Concentration

  • Reaction velocity initially rises with substrate concentration but eventually plateaus at Vmax when all enzyme molecules are saturated with substrate.
  • At this stage, the rate depends only on how quickly the enzyme releases the product so it can bind new substrate.

choices.text: Km increases while Vmax remains unchanged
Km decreases while Vmax increases
Km remains unchanged while Vmax decreases
The inhibitor structurally resembles the substrate and binds at the active site

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the type of enzyme inhibition depicted in the Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The type of enzyme inhibition depicted is non-competitive inhibition (altered y-intercept but same x-intercept) and the true statement regarding non-competitive inhibition is Km remains unchanged while Vmax decreases.

  • In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site and usually have no structural resemblance to the substrate. (Option D ruled out)
  • This binding does not interfere with substrate attachment, so both enzyme-substrate (ES) and enzyme-inhibitor (EI) complexes can form.
  • However, when the inhibitor is bound, the enzyme's ability to convert substrate into product is reduced, leading to a decrease in Vmax, while Km remains unchanged in simple non-competitive inhibition. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • Both the free enzyme (E) and the enzyme-inhibitor complex (EI) have equal affinity for the substrate, but the enzyme-inhibitor-substrate (EIS) complex produces little to no product.
  • In more complex forms of non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor may alter the enzyme's apparent affinity for the substrate, modifying Km as well.
  • Lineweaver-Burk plots show altered y-intercept but same x-intercept.

choices.text: The mutant enzyme has greater turnover
The mutant enzyme has lower affinity but still higher catalytic efficiency
The mutant enzyme has higher efficiency and higher affinity
Both the enzymes have similar catalytic efficiency

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with chronic kidney disease is enrolled in a clinical trial testing a new isoform of urease enzyme for use in hemodialysis patients. Researchers compare its kinetics with the normal enzyme:

.Normal urease: Km = 2 mM, kcat = 400 s⁻¹
Mutant urease: Km = 0.5 mM, kcat = 100 s⁻¹

Which of the following statements regarding the catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) of the mutant enzyme is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both the enzymes have similar catalytic efficiency

Catalytic Constant (kcat)

  • Used to describe the activity of a pure enzyme preparation.
  • Also called the turnover number: how many substrate molecules are converted to product per unit time by one active site of the enzyme. (Option A ruled out)
  • Formula:
    • kcat = Vmax / [E]t, where [E]t is the total concentration of enzyme active sites.
    • Units: reciprocal time (e.g., s⁻¹).

Catalytic Efficiency (kcat/Km)

  • Reflects how effectively an enzyme converts substrate to product.
  • Accounts for both kcat (maximum capacity of the enzyme) and Km (substrate affinity).
  • Km = substrate concentration at which velocity is half of Vmax
  • Higher Km → lower affinity (need more substrate to achieve same rate). (Option B ruled out)
  • A high kcat alone is not sufficient; efficiency also requires a low Km, meaning the enzyme works effectively even at low substrate concentrations.
  • Therefore, kcat/Km is the best measure of enzyme efficiency and allows comparison of: Different enzymes, different substrates for the same enzyme, and forward vs reverse catalytic activity.

Catalytic efficiency of normal urease = 400/2 = 200 s⁻¹ mM⁻¹

Catalytic efficiency of mutant urease = 100/0.5 = 200 s⁻¹ mM⁻¹

Both the enzymes have the same catalytic efficiency (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: 1 ATP, 1 NADH, 2 FADH₂
1 GTP, 3 NADH, 1 FADH₂
2 GTP, 2 NADH, 2 FADH₂
1 ATP, 2 NADH, 1 FADH₂

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with chronic alcoholism presents with weakness and shortness of breath. Labs reveal lactic acidosis and thiamine deficiency. His physician explains that due to impaired activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, his ATP production from the Krebs cycle is significantly reduced. Under normal conditions, complete oxidation of one molecule of acetyl-CoA in the Krebs cycle generates which of the following energy equivalents (before accounting for oxidative phosphorylation of NADH and FADH₂)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under normal conditions, complete oxidation of one molecule of acetyl-CoA in the Krebs cycle generates 1 GTP, 3 NADH, 1 FADH₂ before accounting for oxidative phosphorylation of NADH and FADH₂.

Citric Acid Cycle

Biomedical importance:

  • The citric acid cycle (Krebs or tricarboxylic acid cycle) occurs in mitochondria and is the final pathway for oxidizing carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.
  • Acetyl-CoA from glucose, fatty acids, or amino acids enters the cycle, producing CO₂, and reducing equivalents (NADH, FADH₂) and ATP.
  • It also supports gluconeogenesis, lipogenesis, and amino acid interconversions. Since the liver is central to these processes, damage such as hepatitis or cirrhosis disrupts the cycle.
  • Disorders like hyperammonemia impair the cycle by depleting α-ketoglutarate and blocking ATP formation, leading to neurological problems.

Link to respiratory chain:

  • The cycle starts when acetyl-CoA combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate. T
  • hrough successive steps, two molecules of CO₂ are released, and oxaloacetate is regenerated, allowing the cycle to continue.
  • Enzymes are located in the mitochondrial matrix and inner membrane. The reduced coenzymes produced feed into the electron transport chain to generate ATP.

Key reactions and enzymes:

  1. Citrate synthase: acetyl-CoA + oxaloacetate → citrate.
  2. Aconitase: citrate ↔ isocitrate.
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: isocitrate → α-ketoglutarate (releases CO₂, NADH).
  4. α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase complex: α-ketoglutarate → succinyl-CoA (releases CO₂, NADH).
    • Requires thiamine, lipoate, NAD⁺, FAD, and CoA.
    • Inhibited by arsenite and high ammonia.
  5. Succinyl-CoA synthetase (thiokinase): succinyl-CoA → succinate (produces GTP/ATP).
  6. Succinate dehydrogenase: succinate → fumarate (produces FADH₂).
    • Bound to the mitochondrial membrane, part of respiratory chain.
  7. Fumarase: fumarate → malate.
  8. Malate dehydrogenase: malate → oxaloacetate (produces NADH).

Energy yield per cycle (one acetyl-CoA):

  • 3 NADH → ~7.5 ATP (2.5 ATP per NADH)
  • 1 FADH₂ → ~1.5 ATP
  • 1 GTP (or ATP) → 1 ATP
  • Total: ~10 ATP per turn.

Special points:

  • Anaplerosis: replenishment of intermediates (e.g., pyruvate → oxaloacetate).
  • Cataplerosis: withdrawal of intermediates (e.g., citrate export for fatty acid synthesis

choices.text: Stops proton pumping at Complex IV, collapsing the proton gradient and abolishing ATP synthesis
Reduces ATP yield by blocking Complex I
Allows continued proton pumping but prevents ATP synthase from utilizing the gradient
Increases oxygen consumption but decreases ATP yield due to uncoupling of oxidation and phosphorylation

questions.text: A 30-year-old laboratory worker collapses after inhaling fumes during a chemical accident. He is found to have lactic acidosis and bright red venous blood. Cyanide poisoning is suspected. From a bioenergetics perspective, which of the following best describes the effect of cyanide on mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cyanide stops proton pumping at Complex IV, collapsing the proton gradient and abolishing ATP synthesis.

Respiratory Chain & Oxidative Phosphorylation

Biomedical Importance

  • Mitochondria are the key sites for respiration, producing ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Inhibitors such as cyanide and carbon monoxide can block this process, leading to severe consequences like lactic acidosis, encephalopathy, and myopathy.

Compartmentalization of Enzymes

  • The mitochondrion has a double membrane. The outer membrane is permeable to many metabolites, while the inner membrane is highly selective and hosts critical enzymes such as acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.
  • The inner membrane also contains the respiratory chain, ATP synthase, and transport proteins.

Respiratory Chain Function

  • The respiratory chain captures electrons from carbohydrate, fat, and protein oxidation, transferring them through complexes I-IV embedded in the inner membrane.
  • This process reduces oxygen to water and traps energy in ATP.

Electron Transfer Components

  • The following diagram illustrates how electrons move through the respiratory chain complexes, highlighting where reducing equivalents from key substrates enter.
  • Coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) and cytochrome c serve as mobile carriers within the system.
  • (Abbreviations: cyt = cytochrome, ETF = electron-transferring flavoprotein, Fe-S = iron-sulfur protein, Q = coenzyme Q/ubiquinone).
  • Flavoproteins (FMN, FAD) and iron-sulfur proteins (Fe-S) are key electron carriers.
  • Coenzyme Q (ubiquinone) shuttles electrons between complexes.
  • Cytochromes (b, c1, c, a, a3) carry electrons through redox reactions.
  • Complex IV reduces O₂ to H₂O, tightly controlling the reaction to minimize harmful intermediates.

Proton Gradient & ATP Formation

  • As electrons pass through the chain, protons are pumped across the inner mitochondrial membrane (Complexes I, III, IV).
  • This generates the proton motive force, which powers ATP synthesis via ATP synthase (F₀F₁ complex).
  • The rotary mechanism of ATP synthase couples proton flow to ATP formation through conformational changes in its β-subunits.

Energy Yield

  • For each NADH oxidized, about 2.5 ATP are produced.
  • For FADH₂, about 1.5 ATP are produced.
  • Including substrate-level phosphorylation, nearly 90% of cellular ATP comes from oxidative phosphorylation.

Inhibitors & Poisons

  • Complex I inhibitors: Barbiturates (e.g., amobarbital), rotenone
  • Complex II inhibitors: Malonate (competitive).
  • Complex III inhibitors: Antimycin A, dimercaprol.
  • Complex IV inhibitors: H₂S, cyanide, CO.
  • ATP synthase inhibitors:
  • Uncouplers (e.g., 2,4-DNP, thermogenin): Increase proton leak, causing heat generation instead of ATP.

Chemiosmotic Theory

  • Explains how proton translocation across the membrane creates an electrochemical gradient that drives ATP synthesis.
  • Uncouplers disrupt this gradient, allowing oxidation without ATP production.

Explanation of other options:

Reduces ATP yield by blocking Complex I (Option B): Describes complex I inhibitors such as amobarbital.

Allows continued proton pumping but prevents ATP synthase from utilizing the gradient (Option C): Describes ATP synthase inhibitors such as oligomycin.

Increases oxygen consumption but decreases ATP yield due to uncoupling of oxidation and phosphorylation (Option D): Describes uncouplers such as dinitrophenol.

choices.text: Failure of carnitine-mediated transport of fatty acids into mitochondria
Direct inhibition of ATP synthase, preventing proton-driven ATP generation
Increased acetyl-CoA supply limits both the TCA cycle and ketone body formation
Reduced NADH and FADH₂ production from fatty acid oxidation, leading to impaired oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought with recurrent episodes of vomiting, lethargy, and seizures, especially after overnight fasting. During one episode, his labs show hypoglycemia, very low ketone bodies, and elevated dicarboxylic acids in urine. From a bioenergetics perspective, which of the following best explains why this child cannot maintain adequate ATP levels during fasting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most probable diagnosis based on the clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypoketosis, and elevated dicarboxylic acids in urine is medium chain fatty Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency which is an inherited disorder of β-Oxidation of Fatty Acids which leads to reduced NADH and FADH₂ production from fatty acid oxidation, leading to impaired oxidative phosphorylation.

β-Oxidation of Fatty Acids

β-oxidation occurs in cycles of four steps targeting the β-carbon (third carbon).

The sequence involves:

  1. Oxidation - produces FADH₂.
  2. Hydration
  3. Second oxidation - produces NADH.
  4. Thiolytic cleavage - releases acetyl-CoA.
    • Each cycle shortens the fatty acid chain by two carbons and generates one acetyl-CoA, one NADH, and one FADH₂.
    • The process repeats until the entire fatty acid is degraded; the final round yields two acetyl-CoA molecules.
    • Reduced coenzymes (NADH, FADH₂) enter the electron transport chain for ATP generation.
    • Acetyl-CoA acts as a positive regulator of pyruvate carboxylase, linking fatty acid breakdown with gluconeogenesis.

Medium-Chain Fatty Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase (MCAD) Deficiency

  • Mitochondria contain four types of acyl-CoA dehydrogenases, each specialized for short-, medium-, long-, or very-long-chain fatty acids.
  • MCAD deficiency is the most common inherited disorder of β-oxidation.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Defective oxidation of 6-10 carbon fatty acids leads to:
    • Reduced acetyl-CoA (Option C ruled out)
    • Increased dependence on glucose for energy.
    • Hypoketotic hypoglycemia during fasting or illness.
  • Clinical findings: accumulation of medium-chain acylcarnitines and dicarboxylic acids in urine.
  • Management: avoidance of fasting to prevent metabolic crises.

Explanation of other options:

Failure of carnitine-mediated transport of fatty acids into mitochondria (Option A): Describes primary carnitine deficiency or CPT-I deficiency, not MCAD

Direct inhibition of ATP synthase, preventing proton-driven ATP generation (Option B): Describes oligomycin, not MCAD.

choices.text: 4 ATP
2 ATP
6 ATP
8 ATP

questions.text: A 24-year-old marathon runner collapses at the finish line. He is dehydrated, tachycardic, and has lactic acidosis. His physician explains that during prolonged oxygen deprivation in exercising muscle, ATP production shifts entirely to anaerobic glycolysis. From one molecule of glucose under these anaerobic conditions, how many net ATP molecules are generated in skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under anaerobic conditions, the net ATP molecules generated from one molecule of glucose in skeletal muscle is 2 ATP.

Biomedical Importance of Glycolysis

  • Glucose is a vital fuel for nearly all tissues, with the brain heavily dependent on it except during prolonged fasting when ketones take over partially.
  • Glycolysis, occurring in the cytosol, is the central pathway for glucose and carbohydrate breakdown. It operates both in the presence and absence of oxygen.
  • Red blood cells rely solely on anaerobic glycolysis since they lack mitochondria.
  • Anaerobic glycolysis allows skeletal muscle to generate energy during intense activity when oxygen supply is limited, helping tissues withstand oxygen shortage.
  • In contrast, cardiac muscle has lower glycolytic activity, making it more vulnerable under ischemic conditions.
  • The steps of glycolysis are shown below.

Glycolysis in Anaerobic Conditions

  • Anaerobic glycolysis resembles fermentation and is observed in contracting muscle when oxygen is scarce.
  • Under these conditions, glycogen is broken down, lactate accumulates, and ATP continues to be produced without mitochondrial involvement.
  • When oxygen returns, lactate production halts as pyruvate and NADH are oxidized in the mitochondria.
  • In low oxygen, NADH cannot be reoxidized through the electron transport chain, and pyruvate accepts electrons and is reduced to lactate. This maintains NAD⁺ supply, allowing glycolysis to persist.
  • However, anaerobic glycolysis is less efficient, generating far less ATP per glucose molecule (2 ATP) compared to aerobic metabolism, requiring higher glucose consumption to meet energy needs. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • In yeast and some microbes, anaerobic glycolysis leads not to lactate but to ethanol production through decarboxylation and reduction steps.

choices.text: Low serum ceruloplasmin -increased urinary copper -decreased serum copper
Low serum copper with low ceruloplasmin and normal urinary copper excretion
Undetectable ceruloplasmin with markedly low serum copper and iron accumulation
Elevated serum ceruloplasmin with reduced urinary copper

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought with behavioral changes, difficulty speaking, and tremors. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly and mild jaundice. Ophthalmologic exam shows a brownish ring at the corneal margin. Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical features is Wilson's disease and among the given options, low serum ceruloplasmin - increased urinary copper - decreased serum copper is consistent with this condition.

Wilson's disease

  • An autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective copper transport due to mutations in ATP7B.
  • Leads to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs.

Clinical Phenotypes

Hepatic:

  • Jaundice, hepatomegaly, ascites, edema, splenomegaly.
  • Cirrhosis and chronic hepatitis common.

Neurological:

  • Dysarthria, dystonia, tremor (wing-beating type), abnormal gait, seizures, parkinsonian features.
  • Psychiatric manifestations: irritability, mood changes, poor academic performance, depression, or psychosis.

Ocular:

  • Kayser-Fleischer rings (copper in corneal Descemet's membrane)
  • Sunflower cataract.

Other effects:

  • Hemolytic anemia due to copper-induced red cell membrane damage.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: osteoporosis, rickets, osteoarthritis.
  • Renal issues: aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, nephrolithiasis.

Biochemical Findings

  • Low serum ceruloplasmin and reduced total serum copper.
  • Increased urinary copper excretion (>100 µg/day). (Option D ruled out)
  • High hepatic copper content (>200 µg/g dry weight).
  • Radiolabeled copper tests show poor incorporation into ceruloplasmin.

Molecular Basis

  • Caused by loss-of-function mutations in ATP7B, a P-type ATPase responsible for copper excretion into bile and incorporation into ceruloplasmin.

Diagnosis

  • Based on combination of clinical, biochemical, and genetic tests.
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings are a key diagnostic sign, especially in neurologic presentations.
  • A validated scoring system (Leipzig) integrates clinical, lab, and genetic data.

Treatment

Copper Chelation:

  • Penicillamine (first-line) - binds copper for urinary excretion; requires pyridoxine supplementation.
  • Trientine - alternative chelator with fewer side effects.
  • Tetrathiomolybdate - reduces copper absorption and free copper levels.

Zinc Therapy:

  • Blocks intestinal copper absorption by inducing metallothionein.
  • Used in presymptomatic patients, pregnant women, or as maintenance therapy.

Liver Transplantation:

  • Reserved for fulminant hepatic failure or end-stage disease unresponsive to therapy.
  • Can correct both hepatic and neurologic symptoms.

Explanation of other options:

Low serum copper with low ceruloplasmin and normal urinary copper excretion (Option B): Describes Menke disease

Undetectable ceruloplasmin with markedly low serum copper and iron but tissue iron overload (Option C): Suggestive of aceruloplasminemia.
